intro: Chamaesaracha geohintonii, commonly known as Hinton's rock cress, is a rare and endemic flowering plant native to the mountainous regions of southern Africa. It belongs to the Brassicaceae family, which includes mustard and cabbage plants, and is characterized by its small, cruciform flowers. The plant typically grows in rocky or limestone habitats, showcasing adaptations to arid and nutrient-poor environments. Its leaves are basal and pinnately lobed, while its flowers are usually pale yellow or white. Due to its limited distribution and habitat specificity, it is considered a species of conservation concern.
